caption_original: The clouds Ô∏è pictured are called mammatus. Mammatus are formed from outpouching of water vapour high in the atmosphere. They are often (but not always) seen in the anvil of strong thunderstorms, as was the case on this summer day!.... : Kyle Fougere

caption_original: The cloud pictured is called a supercell thunderstorm. Supercell thunderstorms have a rotating updraft, and are almost always associated with severe weather. They often look like a barber pole or in some cases, a UFO!....: Kyle Fougere

caption_original: We have a season-long program on Country Island, Nova Scotia to protect the Roseate Tern colony and assess their productivity. One of the biggest jobs each season is to count the number of active Tern nests and in order to do that we usually bring a few extra people onto the island because of the number of nests and the fact that they‚Äôre often in challenging vegetation and so hard to see!! This means, all hands on deck ‚Ä¶even directors and managers go on field trips! With views like these, who wouldn‚Äôt like to get out in the field to work? Yes CWS, the social media team is extremely jealous.... : Garry Donaldson

caption_original: Did you know that endangered species conservation is sometimes complex and multi-national? This endangered burrowing owl was fitted with a satellite transmitter near her nest in Alberta in . The solar-powered transmitter allows scientists with the Canadian Wildlife Service and project collaborators to track her movements wherever she goes. After leaving her burrow in Alberta this bird flew over ,500km to winter in Central Mexico. In spring she returned to Alberta and nested less than km from where she was first captured. She was recently sighted by biologists in Mexico in the same wintering site as the year before, and we are hoping she makes a safe and successful return to Canada to raise the next generation of owls. ü¶â....

caption_original: These photos were taken during the Piping Plover census that takes place every five years throughout its breeding range which in Canada includes the prairies, Great Lakes, Quebec and Atlantic Canada. In this set of pictures Andrew and Garry spent the day on Shediac Island which is off the coast of New Brunswick in the Northumberland Strait. caption_original: On this photo, Josh is dusting it up at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA) in Saskatchewan. This biologist is helping to restore migratory bird and wildlife habitat by seeding native prairie grasses and wildflowers. Not far down the road is biologist Denise, checking her progress as she tends to a young restoration area. Mowing reduces weeds and help new grassland plants to thrive! Soon enough these areas will be teeming with Savannah Sparrows, Deer Mice, Red-Backed Voles, Swainson‚Äôs and Red-Tailed Hawks.....

caption_original: Meet our Conservation Biologists Karen and Julie and Wildlife Enforcement Officer Ryan. They‚Äôre at Halifax‚Äôs McNabs Island, home to one of Nova Scotia‚Äôs biggest barn swallow colonies. Although barn swallows are one of the world‚Äôs most widespread and common land bird species, populations in Canada have declined by % since the s.
